awd_titl_txt: CAREER: What sets the CO2 thermostat? Insights from the global geochemical cycles of Ca, Mg, and K
awd_abstract_narration:
Feedbacks between Earth's climate, the global carbon cycle, and the composition of seawater constitute one of the primary mechanisms invoked for maintaining habitable conditions on our planet over much of its 4 billion year history. This project seeks to provide a new foundation for our understanding of the marine processes that play a significant but underappreciated role in moderating Earth's chemical cycles through time. The research component of this CAREER award would involve the development and application of new analytical methods and tools to investigate some of the most poorly understood ways in which the chemical balance of the oceans is maintained. CAREER awards are also designed to support particularly strong educational efforts and the integration of research and education. To this end, Higgins proposes an educational monitoring program of urban tap water in Trenton, NJ in collaboration with Isles, Inc., a community development organization. This project would be carried out by teams consisting of Isles, Inc. employees, community volunteers, Trenton students, Princeton undergraduates, the lead investigator, and a postdoctoral investigator. Students would learn the steps of the scientific method through an investigation of the chemistry of their home tap water, get exposure to the nuts-and-bolts behind how science works, and develop an appreciation for how science can empower an individual and impact a community. 

The PI proposes to investigate marine processes that affect the flow of cations, alkalinity, and CO2 through the ocean-atmosphere system with the targeted application of high-precision high-throughput measurements of stable isotope ratios of magnesium (26Mg/24Mg), calcium (44Ca/42Ca), and potassium (41K/39K) by multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC ICP-MS). Specific research topics that will be pursued are 1) Global sinks of Mg and K in authigenic marine clays, 2) Global fluxes of Mg and Ca associated with diagenesis of shallow-water carbonate sediments, and 3) Global fluxes of Mg and Ca in low temperature seafloor hydrothermal systems. Approaches include laboratory experiments as well as analysis of sediment and pore-fluid samples.

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER proposal sought to make fundamental contributions to our understanding of the mechanisms and magnitudes of processes that drive the flow of cations and carbon through the ocean-atmosphere system with the targeted application of high-precision high-throughput measurements of stable isotope ratios of magnesium (26Mg/24Mg), calcium (44Ca/42Ca), and potassium (41K/39K). In this regard the proposal was successful; it contributed to the publication of 7 peer-reviewed publications (Dunlea et al., 2017; Ahm et al., 2018, Higgins et al., 2018, Ramos et al., 2018, Ahm et al., 2019, Ramos et al., 2020, Ahm et al., 2021) and 1 more in review (Akhtar et al., GCA). Each one of the published manuscripts is described briefly below.

Using measurements of Mg isotopes in bulk marine clays, Dunlea et al., (2017) proposes a new mechanism for the decline in Mg-clay formation that led to the rise in Mg/Casw. We hypothesized that the rise of marine diatoms and the associated shift in the global distribution of biogenic silica burial led to a re-localization of the silica deposition required for clay formation. In addition to providing a novel link between well-known events in biological evolution and global changes in seawater chemistry, this hypothesis provides a new explanation for declining atmospheric CO2 and global cooling since 50 Ma. 

Ahm et al., (2018) and Higgins et al., (2018) represent important contributions to our understanding of early marine diagenesis in shallow marine carbonate sediments. These studies demonstrate that early marine diagenesis is ubiquitous in shallow-water marine carbonate sediments, associated with large fluxes Ca to/from seawater, and capable of driving major changes in sediment geochemistry and mineralogy. This is shown in Higgins et al., (2018) through a dataset of paired Ca and Mg isotope measurements from Neogene sediments that contain both primary and diagenetic carbonate minerals. Ahm et al., (2018) developed a quantitative numerical model of sediment diagenesis and used it to understand how early marine diagenesis produces bulk sediments that express a range of geochemical compositions (e.g. sediment-buffered to fluid-buffered).  Together these papers provide a roadmap for reconstructing the chemical composition of seawater over Earth history using 'snapshots' of diagenetically altered shallow-water marine carbonates. 

Ahm et al., (2019) and Ahm et al., (2021) represent applications of the framework developed by Ahm et al., (2018) and Higgins et al., (2018) to events in the geologic record. Ahm et al., (2019) shows that the diagenetic fingerprint identified by Higgins et al., (2018) and Ahm et al., (2018) is present in Neoproterozoic carbonate sediments that cap Snowball Earth glacial deposits. Ahm et al., (2019) shows that the geochemistry and dolomitization of the cap carbonates can be understood as the consequence of early marine diagenesis associated with the growth and dissipation of a global meltwater lens. Ahm et al., (2021) expands this further by applying the same framework to understanding the carbonate sediments deposited just prior to the latest Neoproterozoic glaciation. 

Ramos et al., (2018) and Ramos et al., (2020) both represent important contributions to the study of the global K cycle in seawater through the use of stable isotopes (41K/39K). Ramos et al., (2018) document, for the first time, large K isotope variability in deep-sea pore-fluids which we were able to quantitatively attribute to both the effects of aqueous diffusion and mineral-specific isotopic fractionation (clay formation). Ramos et al, (2020) investigates an important sink in the global K cycle - low temperature alteration of oceanic crust - to establish, again for the first time, the extent to which this sink fractionates K isotopes (they do, but cannot fully explain the elevated 41K/39K of seawater relative to bulk silicate Earth). 

Another equally important aspect of this CAREER proposal was to help establish a new undergraduate service course. The course offers undergraduates a unique opportunity to get hands-on experience with state-of-the-art analytical tools (mass spectrometry and handheld X-ray fluorescence) while providing a service to the local community. The course partners with Isles Inc., a community development organization with more than 20 years of experience working with Trenton, NJ residents on lead poisoning and other local environmental threats, to provide a no-cost monitoring program for lead in urban tap water, paint, and soil. Students participate in home visits with Isles community health workers to collect tap water samples and analyze the homes for lead in paint and soil. Students then analyze tap water samples in my laboratory, reduce the data, interpret the results, and provide the information to Isles to inform remediation work. The course offers undergraduates an opportunity to develop laboratory skills while engaging in the scientific process and forging bonds with the local New Jersey community in a way that provides concrete benefits to everyone involved. The course, which has run for 5 years, has trained 48 undergraduates, visited over 50 homes, and analyzed water samples > 1000 households at no cost.
